ContentNode.title: Health Reporting and Monitoring 5.2.1
1. Overview

LocaleContent.title: 1. Overview
LocaleContent.content:
VMware Validated Solutions are a Use-case driven, fully validated, VMware technical design which can be rapidly implemented by customers on VMware Cloud Foundation. 

In this lab you are going to implement VMware Cloud Foundation Health Reporting and Monitoring based on the VMware Validated Solutions Documentation, which can be found here. Have a look if you are not familiar.

As with all the VMware Validated Solutions  Documentation the VMware Cloud Foundation Health Reporting and Monitoring VVS strives to provide best practice decisions around placement, solution architecture, customer hand off/knowledge transfer, etc.

For the purposes of this Hands On Lab we will focus on the following workflow. Which of course comes directly from the VVS Documentation.

Stage Steps
1. Plan and prepare the VMware Cloud Foundation environment.
  1. Work with the technology team of your organization to configure the physical servers, network, and storage in the data center. Collect the environment details and write them down in the VMware Cloud Foundation Planning and Preparation Workbook.
2. Install and configure the PowerShell Module for VMware Cloud Foundation Reporting.
  1. Deploy and configure a host virtual machine.
  2. Install the PowerShell Module for VMware Cloud Foundation Reporting and supporting PowerShell modules from the PowerShell Gallery.
3. Install and configure the Python Module for VMware Cloud Foundation Health Monitoring in VMware Aria Operations.
  1. Install and configure the Python Module for VMware Cloud Foundation Health Monitoring in VMware Aria Operations and its dependencies.
  2. Install the Python client for VMware Aria Operations.
  3. Configure VMware Aria Operations with the provided monitoring artifacts - dashboards, views, super metrics, alerts, and notifications.

ContentNode.title: 2. The SoS Utility - Where Operations gets it's HRM Data
SSH to the SDDC-Manager

LocaleContent.title: SSH to the SDDC-Manager
LocaleContent.content:
You can use the labs resources to do a quick primer on the SoS Utility.

Open PuTTY, Double Click the SDDC-Manager Entry.

SSH keys are in place so you should auto log in

cd to the sddc-support directory

cd /opt/vmware/sddc-support

run a quick test to make sure you are in the right directory and the SoS utility is present

sudo ./sos -v

Enter the vcf password

VMware123!VMware123!

You might want to expand the putty window out a bit, the data that will come back from the SoS utility can be somewhat wide

From the doc you can learn how to use the SoS Utility to gather and export data from the sddc manager, and export that data to logs, json, etc. From the very top of the list of checks, you are going to run the certificate-health check, which verifies that the component certificates are valid (within the expiry date).

To do so simply Run this command

sudo ./sos --certificate-health

Spend some more time in the SoS Utility doc, work through some use cases you can think of. You can get a better understanding of what data the VCF HRM Management Pack for Operations can supply, where it comes from and how to start troubleshooting if the Pack is not performing as expected. One common issue we in Livefire hear from the field is how long the data can take to come back. This lab is small, it only has 4 hosts in Site 1. The simple example shown takes around 55 seconds to come back. Imagine if the customer has 50, 100 or more hosts. These health checks will take quite a while to run. This needs to be taken into consideration while setting up and relying on the VCF HRM Management Pack for Operations.

Move onto the next section of the lab, where you will use VVS provided Powershell Scripts to run the same API calls into VCF and export the data into a static Local HTML Report.

LocaleContent.title: 2. The SoS Utility - Where Operations gets it's HRM Data
LocaleContent.content:
As shown in the previous section the VMware Cloud Foundation Health Reporting and Monitoring Solution makes use of the "SoS Utility"

The Support-ability and Serviceability (SoS) Utility is a command-line tool that you can use to run health checks, collect logs for VMware Cloud Foundation components, and so on. To run the SoS utility, SSH in to the SDDC Manager appliance using the vcf user account.

This lab is just a simple intro, the Health Reporting and Monitoring solutions uses the same APIs and sources to gather it's data before it is sent to Operations to be used with the VCF HRM Management Pack. Knowledge of how to access and use the SoS Utility is a good place to start if you need trouble shoot the Operations HRM Managment Pack for your customer.

At the wrirting of this manual the latest doc on the SoSUtility can be found at

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/5.1/vcf-deploy/GUID-10BA552D-FE25-4DF4-AFCA-F8A520DD881C.html

ContentNode.title: 3. Use the PowerShell/Python Module Locally for VMware Cloud Foundation Reporting
Local Reports

LocaleContent.title: Local Reports
LocaleContent.content:
As stated earlier the VMware Cloud Foundation Health Reporting and Monitoring Solution enlists a "Host Machine/Collector Node" that is used for the data integration between VCF and Operations. The data extract tools are based in Powershell and Python

In this part of the lab we wanted to demonstrate how you can pull these scripts locally and use them to run useful reports manually. We have pulled these scripts down for you to the Windows Holo-Console Jumpbox you have RDPed to

ContentNode.title: Review and Modify Report Configuration

LocaleContent.title: Review and Modify Report Configuration
LocaleContent.content:
To get started, on the Holo-Console

  • Open the Windows Explorer and navigate to c:\VLC\VLC-Holo-Site-1\Holo-Reporting
  • Right click runReport.ps1 and click Open with Code. This file shows all the environment variables needed by the reporting module to deliver reports.
  • If the following lines are not already in the file, add them to the file and save it.
Invoke-VcfOverviewReport -sddcManagerFqdn $sddcManagerFqdn -sddcManagerUser $sddcManagerUser -sddcManagerPass $sddcManagerPass -reportPath $reportPath -darkMode
Invoke-VcfHealthReport -sddcManagerFqdn $sddcManagerFqdn -sddcManagerUser $sddcManagerUser -sddcManagerPass $sddcManagerPass -sddcManagerLocalUser $sddcManagerLocalUser -sddcManagerLocalPass $sddcManagerLocalPass -reportPath $reportPath -allDomains -darkMode
Invoke-VcfConfigReport -sddcManagerFqdn $sddcManagerFqdn -sddcManagerUser $sddcManagerUser -sddcManagerPass $sddcManagerPass -reportPath $reportPath -allDomains -darkMode
Invoke-VcfAlertReport -sddcManagerFqdn $sddcManagerFqdn -sddcManagerUser $sddcManagerUser -sddcManagerPass $sddcManagerPass -reportPath $reportPath -allDomains -darkMode

NOTE: Only Four Lines from the above command block should now be in the script. The top two may already be there. Simply Overwrite them with your copy and paste. Don't forget to save the ps1 file

Be sure to open Powershell from the taskbar, the jumpbox has an older version of Powershell that will not work. So don't open Powershell ISE just use the icon on the taskbar.  

  • Within Holo-Console, open a PowerShell window as administrator
  • Change directory to C:\VLC\VLC-Holo-Site-1\Holo-Reporting
  • Type  .\runReports.ps1 and press enter

You can monitor the progress of the reporting scripts by viewing the PowerShell Window.

You may see a couple of errors along then way.  If the report process does not complete after 10 minutes, press CTRL + X to break the script process, it will then move on to the next report.

  • The output will be displayed as a series of web pages that open automatically in Chrome.  It will take around 6 minutes for all the reports to open.  Take some time to review the content of the reports.  This is useful information when you are preparing for an upgrade, reviewing an existing deployment, or creating documentation for a new deployment.

LocaleContent.title: Create Virtual Machine for the Host Virtual Machine for Health Reporting and Monitoring for VMware Cloud Foundation
LocaleContent.content:
The Health Reporting and Monitoring Validated Solution uses a custom "host machine", Operations Cloud Proxy, also know as a "collector node" to run the data collection scripts and then push the output to Operations.

The "host virtual machine" can be a Photon OS or Windows Server based operating system that adheres to your customer's standards.

For purposes of the lab we will use a sample appliance provided by the VVS team. This appliance comes with all necessary OS packages. If your customer requires you to deploy a host virtual machine based on their specs, you must install the following packages:

  • logrotate
  • wget
  • git
  • unzip
  • tar
  • jq
  • cronie
  • powershell
  • python3-pip

Full documentation for a custom build of the host machine can be found - https://techdocs.broadcom.com/us/en/vmware-cis/vcf/vvs/1-0/health-reporting-and-monitoring-for-vmware-cloud-foundation/implementation-for-health-monitoring/implementation-of-health-reporting-and-monitoring-using-component-user-interfaces/configure-the-host-virtual-machine-for-health-reporting-and-monitoring.html#GUID-DD1B7D6C-F26A-4E03-91F8-04FB0A701E0C-en

ContentNode.title: Install and Configure the Python Module for VMware Cloud Foundation Health Monitoring in VMware Aria Operations

LocaleContent.title: Install and Configure the Python Module for VMware Cloud Foundation Health Monitoring in VMware Aria Operations
LocaleContent.content:
Upload the Python Module for VMware Cloud Foundation Health Monitoring in VMware Aria Operations to the host virtual machine and configure the necessary settings to enable health data collection and the integration with VMware Aria Operations

Install the Python Module for VMware Cloud Foundation Health Monitoring in VMware Aria Operations

pip install vmware-cloud-foundation-health-monitoring --target=/opt/vmware/hrm-sddc_manager

Provide execute permissions to the files in the hrm directory

chmod -R 755 /opt/vmware/hrm-sddc_manager

Switch to the hrm-<sddc_manager_vm_name>/main directory.

cd /opt/vmware/hrm-sddc_manager/main

Now you need to set the environment variables used by the scripts. Run cat against the env.json file to see what needs to change

cat env.json

The lines that need to be modified have been highlighted here.

As you are about to make some changes make a backup of the env.json file so you can always reset back to base

cp env.json env.json.bak

In env.json file provided by the VVS you will see the block above. You need to change the settings for Operations FQDN and the User the scripts will use to connect and push data.

FQDN: aria-ops.vcf.sddc.lab
User: svc-hrm-ops@Holodeck AD

Then the same for the FQDN for the SDDC manager and the Users used to connect and extract data from the SDDC Manager, you will see this block in the supplied env.json file. Changes based on:

FQDN: sddc-manager.vcf.sddc.lab
User: svc-hrm-vcf@vcf.holo.lab
Local User: vcf

Of course you can vi or vim this file and make the changes manually, but since we have sed, and automation is the heart and soul of the VVS, here are the sed commands that should make all the changes for you. Copy and paste the block below

sed -i 's/xint-vrops01.rainpole.io/aria-ops.vcf.sddc.lab/' env.json
sed -i 's/svc-hrm-vrops@sfo.rainpole.io@vIDMAuthSource/svc-hrm-ops@Holodeck AD/' env.json
sed -i 's/sfo-vcf01.sfo.rainpole.io/sddc-manager.vcf.sddc.lab/' env.json
sed -i 's/svc-hrm-vcf@sfo.rainpole.io/svc-hrm-vcf@vcf.holo.lab/' env.json
cat env.json

Now we need to set and encrypt the passwords used. Luckily for us the password is VMware123! in the lab.

Run the encrypt-password script

python encrypt-passwords.py

ContentNode.title: Schedule the Python Module for VMware Cloud Foundation Health Reporting in VMware Aria Operations to Run Daily

LocaleContent.title: Schedule the Python Module for VMware Cloud Foundation Health Reporting in VMware Aria Operations to Run Daily
LocaleContent.content:
The last part of setting up the host machines is to Automate sending health data to VMware Aria Operations by scheduling the Python module to run daily. We do this with cron.

Edit the cron tab.

crontab -e

Add the following to the file

59 23 * * * /usr/bin/python /opt/vmware/hrm-sddc_manager/main/send-data-to-vrops.py > /dev/null 2>&1
crontab -l

Adjust the cron tab as needed for scheduling of data extract and import. Take into consideration large environments will take quite a while for the data to be extracted and pushed. As well as additional VCF Eco system connections.

The sample cron table entry in the VVS, and this lab, will run every day at 23:59.

With that done the last step is to import the pieces of the Health Reporting and Monitoring management pack into Operations.

LocaleContent.title: 1. Creating an Extensibility Subscription with Orchestrator
LocaleContent.content:
By using a Automation Orchestrator integration, or extensibility actions with Automation Assembler, you can create subscriptions to extend your applications.

Extensibility subscriptions allow you to extend your applications by triggering workflows or actions at specific life-cycle events. You can also apply filters to your subscriptions to set Boolean conditions for the specified event. For example, the event and workflow or action only triggers if the Boolean expression is 'true'. This is helpful for scenarios where you want to control when events, actions, or workflows are triggered.

In this lesson we will create an Extensibility Subscription that will trigger an Aria Automation Orchestrator workflow to automatically create a VM snapshot when a specified deployment is completed.

In this lab, we will quickly cover the basics of using Aria Automation Orchestrator and Aria Automation to perform these extensibility tasks.

In this lab we walked through the basics of using Aria Automation Orchestrator and Aria Automation to perform extensibility tasks. There are many other ways to utilize the extensibility within Aria Automation so we hope you'll look at some of the resources at the end of the lab and see what else you can do with these amazing automation and extensibility options.

ContentNode.title: 2. Creating a Custom Day 2 Resource Action Using Orchestrator

LocaleContent.title: 2. Creating a Custom Day 2 Resource Action Using Orchestrator
LocaleContent.content:
After we create a deployment based on a cloud template, we can run different lifecycle (day 2) actions on both the deployment and its resources. Aria Automation Assembler includes many Day 2 actions out of the box, but we might want to create others to meet different requirements. We can achieve this by creating custom Resource Actions.

Resource Actions can be based either on Aria Automation Orchestrator workflows or Action Based Extensibility (ABX) actions and can be applied to embedded resources.

In this lesson we will create a custom Resource Action using Aria Automation Orchestrator to move a deployed vSphere Machine resource to a different vSphere folder.

In this lab, we will quickly cover the basics of using Aria Automation Orchestrator and Aria Automation to perform extensibility tasks.

In this lesson we have successfully created a custom Resource Action which calls an Aria Automation Orchestrator Workflow to complete a Day 2 operational task on a virtual machine resource.  In this example we moved a virtual machine to a new folder in VMware vCenter but the possibilities are only limited by your imagination.

Create a custom Resource Action

While logged to Aria Automation and click on the Assembler Service

  1. Click on the Design Tab
  2. Select Resource Actions
  3. Select + NEW RESOURCE ACTION to begin creating our new Resource Action

We will begin to enter the required information to create the Resource Action:

  1. Enter Move_VM_Folder for the Name of our Resource Action
  2. Enter Move VM to New Folder, this will be the Display name for our Resource Action
  3. Toggle the Activate slider so that we enable the Resource Action
  4. Toggle the Scope slider so that we disable the any project availability
  5. Select the VLC-Holodeck for your project
  6. Click +ADD to add the Resource Type that this action is associated with 
  7. As this Resource action will be for a vSphere Machine we will need to specify this for our Resource Type: Cloud.vSphere.Machine

Now that we have selected our Resource Type we now need to select the workflow that we would like to run against it:

1. Scroll down to view the rest of the form

2. Click +ADD in Action/Workflow to add a workflow

NOTE : Resource Actions can be associated with Aria Automation Orchestrator workflows or ABX Actions, however only a single workflow or action can be selected for each Resource Action. We also cannot combine a workflow and action together within a single Resource Action.

Through the out of the box vSphere integration, Aria Automation Orchestrator comes with an existing workflow to move virtual machines to a folder. This means we do not need to create our own:

  1. In the search field enter Move virtual machine to folder
  2. Select the Move virtual machine to folder workflow from the search results
  3. Click ADD to add it to our Resource Action 

The Property Bindings section on the request form is now populated detailing the Property Bindings.

We use the Property Binding feature to ensure the corresponding workflow or action receives the correct inputs (either manually or automatically) to be able to execute successfully.

There are three Property Binding types:

  • In request which basically means the value will be set at request time via an interactive dialog
  • Direct which basically allows us to define the property (schema) of the resource to pass as a binding
  • With binding action allows us to choose a binding Aria Automation Orchestrator action to run to bind to the Data Type

As there are two Property Bindings listed, the workflow requires two inputs:

  • vm which is of Aria Automation Orchestrator data type, VC:VirtualMachine
  • folder which is of Aria Automation Orchestrator data type, VC:vmFolder

As this Resource Action is related to the Cloud.vSphere.Machine Resource Type, and we need to translate that to the VC:VirtualMachine type, we are going to update the Property Binding to use a binding action to automatically provide the right resource information for the resource the action is being completed on:

ContentNode.title: Lab 2 Intro - Using REST API Calls in Orchestrator

LocaleContent.title: Lab 2 Intro - Using REST API Calls in Orchestrator
LocaleContent.content:
In Orchestrator, REST API Calls enable the automation of various tasks, integration with other systems and tools, and build custom solutions that extend the functionality of the Orchestrator platform. Common use cases include Automation of Provisioning Tasks, Workflow Automation, Integration with Service Management Tools, Configuration Management, Monitoring and Reporting, Cloud Resource Management, Security and Compliance Automation, and Data Integration and Transformation. 

In this lab, we'll have the opportunity to experience the power of utilizing REST API calls within Orchestrator to configure and integrate with vROps (vRealize Operations) and vCLRM (vCloud Lifecycle Manager). Through this hands-on exercise, we'll explore how REST APIs can facilitate seamless communication between Orchestrator and these VMware solutions, enabling efficient configuration management and enhanced integration capabilities.

- Creating  a vROPS configuration Orchestrator workflow using REST API’s

- Creating a vROPs Alert Notification using a Webhook Action

- Creating a vRSLCM configuration Orchestrator workflow using REST API's that will enable content management of vROPs configurations (+ making it a consumable Service Broker catalog item)

Understanding API

Before we begin using API, let's discuss how we gather information like the URL structure, request requirements, and API paths.  This is all done through a popular tool called Swagger UI. You can access the Swagger UI through a web browser by navigating to the Swagger documentation URL  as shown below:

{VROPsFQDN}/suite-api/doc/swagger-ui.html  

In your browser go to the following URL:  https://aria-vrops.vcf.sddc.lab/suite-api/doc/swagger-ui.html

Once you're in Swagger UI, you'll see the API documentation organized into sections such as actions, policies, symptoms, alerts, and auth (authentication). Each endpoint represents a specific API operation that you can perform.

All URL structure require a base URL.  The base URL, also known as the root URL, is the starting point for all API requests. It specifies the domain and protocol where the API is hosted, without including any specific endpoint paths. Typically, the base URL includes the protocol (such as HTTP or HTTPS) and the domain name or IP address of the server hosting the API.

For example, if an API is hosted at "https://vrops.vcf.sddc.lab/suite-api/api/auth/token/acquire", then "https://vrops.vcf.sddc.lab" is the base URL.

The base URL provides a consistent foundation for constructing API requests by appending endpoint paths and query parameters as needed. It allows clients to interact with the API without having to specify the full URL for each request, simplifying the request process and making the API more accessible.

In Swagger UI, you'll find the URL structure for each API endpoint listed along with the HTTP method (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, etc.). The URL structure specifies the path to the endpoint relative to the base URL of the API.  

Swagger also allows API designers to document the content requirements for each endpoint, including request and response payloads. This documentation often includes details such as supported data formats (e.g., JSON or XML), required and optional parameters, data types, and example payloads. By consulting the Swagger documentation, developers can understand exactly what data needs to be provided in each API request and what they can expect to receive in response.

We'll actually use the API below in our next lab to create an Authentication token which will be used in all our vROPs Orchestrator API REST Calls. Take note of the URL, the HTTP Method and the required content.

Now, let's start using REST API Calls!

Configuration elements are used to store settings, parameters, and other data that can be accessed and utilized within workflows or scripts. These configuration elements allow you to centralize and manage various configurations in a structured manner, making it easier to maintain and update settings across multiple workflows.

LocaleContent.title: 1. Creating a vROPS Configuration Using REST APIs in Orchestrator
LocaleContent.content:
In this lab, we'll explore the powerful capabilities of making REST API Calls with Aria Orchestrator to automate the creation of alert and symptom definitions in vRealize Operations (vROps). By leveraging these APIs, we can streamline the configuration process and ensure consistency in monitoring across the environment. We will review how to programmatically create alert definitions in vROps using REST API calls from Aria Orchestrator. and we'll explore the necessary parameters and payload structures required to define custom alerts tailored to our environment's specific needs.

We'll also use both OOTB workflows as well as Custom workflows to complete the tasks as shown.  While OOTB workflows offer convenience and standardization for common tasks, custom workflows provide greater flexibility and customization options tailored to specific organizational needs and integration requirements. The choice between OOTB and custom workflows depends on the complexity of the automation task, the level of customization required, and the expertise of the development team.

In this lab we were successfully able to harness the power of REST API Calls in Aria Orchestrator to automate the creation of alert and symptom definitions in vRealize Operations. We're now be equipped with the knowledge and skills to effectively run API calls to vROps from Orchestrator and integrate the two systems to automate tasks, retrieve data, or perform various management operations as needed.

In the next lab we will use this Alert Definition to define an alert notification.  We'll also create an automated response using a Orchestrator Webhook.

Updating Orchestrator Configuration Elements
  1. Return to the Aria Automation console https://aria-auto.vcf.sddc.lab
  2. Domain - System Domain / username - configadmin / password - VMware123!
  3. Select the 9 dots in the top right hand corner
  4. Select Orchestrator

1. Select Configurations (under Assets) on the left side panel

2. Locate the vROPS Credentials Configuration

Open the vROPS Credentials Configuration

1. Go to the Variable Tab

2. Click on the password Variable

1. Update the value with VMware123!

2. Click SAVE to save the new value

Click SAVE and CLOSE to save the updated configuration

Now that we have the prerequisites sorted out, we can now move on to adding the vROPS REST Host and Operations.  We can then test by using Orchestrator workflows to build a vROPs configuration.

ADD a REST Host

In Orchestrator, you will need to add a REST Host so that you can run API REST Call operations.(discussed next) This will allow Orchestrator to create alert definitions, symptom definitions and add the definitions to an existing policy.

While in Orchestrator, select Workflows from the left panel

1. Filter for Add a REST host    (This is an OOTB workflow)

2. Click on RUN to configure the workflow

We now enter the properties as shown:

Under the Host Properties tab:

  1. Name - vROPs
  2. URL - https://aria-ops.vcf.sddc.lab
  3. Connection timeout - 30
  4. Operation timeout - 60
  5. Certificate - leave unchecked
  6. Parallel executions - leave unchecked
  7. Redirect strategy - defaultRedirect

Under the Host Authentication tab:

  1. Host's Authentication type - Basic

Under the User Credentials tab:

  1. Session mode - Shared Session
  2. Authentication user name - vropsapi
  3. Authentication password - VMware123!

Under the Proxy Settings tab:

1. Leave the Proxy Settings tab as is

Under the SSL tab:

1. Target hostname X.509 cert - leave checked

2. Private KeyEntry - blank

3. Click on RUN to execute

Once the run is complete, you can confirm that the REST Host has been added by viewing the hosts listed under Administration > Inventory > HTTP REST

ADD a REST OPERATION

Now you will need to add a REST Operation which is used to interact with external systems or services via RESTful APIs. In this case, we will first create a REST operation to create an authenticating token. Authentication tokens are essential for securely accessing the vROps REST API, managing sessions, and enforcing access controls, ensuring that only authorized users or applications can interact with the vROps environment via the API.

We'll be adding 4 REST Operations in this task

From the left side, select Workflows

1. Filter for Add a REST operation   (This is an OOTB workflow)

2. Click on RUN to configure the workflow

Enter in the following:

  1. Parent host - vROPS (select the REST Host which was just added)
  2. Name - vROPS API Token
  3. Template URL - /suite-api/api/auth/token/acquire       
  4. HTTP method - POST
  5. Content Type - leave blank
  6. Click on RUN to execute

(NOTE - We reviewed how this info is gathered in the Lab Intro. Also note that because we've already added the REST host using Basic Authentication, we do not have to provide the authentication credentials again when adding an operation. )

Now that we have the token enabling us to run REST operations, let's add a REST operation that will be used to create the alert.  Alerts in vROPS are dependent on Symptoms so in this case we will also create a custom Symptom REST operation.

ALERT DEFINITION REST OPERATION

Click on Add a REST operation and enter the following: 

NOTE: When the lab says “Click on Add a REST operation”, what we’re asking you to do is to run the Add a REST operation” workflow again. To do so, click CLOSE to close the “workflow run”. Then select Library > Workflows from the left side of the screen, then filter for Add a REST operation, then click that workflow’s Run button.

  1. Parent host - vROPS (select the REST Host which was just added)
  2. Name - vROPS add alert definition
  3. Template URL - /suite-api/api/alertdefinitions     (NOTE - We will discuss how to find the API URL later in the lab)
  4. HTTP method - POST
  5. Content Type - leave blank
  6. Click on RUN to execute

SYMPTOM DEFINITION REST OPERATION

Let's repeat the same for the symptom definitions.

Click on Add a REST operation and enter the following:

  1. Parent host - vROPS (select the REST Host which was just added)
  2. Name - vROPS add symptom definition
  3. Template URL - /suite-api/api/symptomdefinitions      
  4. HTTP method - POST
  5. Content Type - leave blank
  6. Click on RUN to execute

ADD ALERT DEFINITION TO POLICY REST OPERATION

Lastly, we will add a REST operation that will integrate the alert definition into a policy.  vROps policies provide a flexible framework for tailoring monitoring and management strategies to the unique needs of an organization, enabling the effective monitoring, analyzing, and optimization of the IT infrastructure.

Click on Add a REST operation again and enter the following:

  1. Parent host - vROPS (select the REST Host which was just added)
  2. Name - vROPS add alert definition to policy
  3. Template URL - /suite-api/api/alertdefinitions/{AlertDefinitionId}/enabled?policyId=f7a83558-bcd5-4776-9e61-42a6c3312a21&_no_links=true   (Note - we will automatically pass the AlertDefinitionId parameter inside the workflow)
  4. HTTP method - PUT
  5. Content Type - application/json
  6. Click on RUN to execute

FYI… That hexadecimal string is the policy ID of the policy called “vSphere Solution’s Default Policy” defined in Aria Operations.

You can look up policy IDs by going to Operations > Configurations > Policy Definition, clicking a policy, then clicking EDIT POLICY, and the tail end of the URL in the address bar is the policy ID for that policy.
For example, 779e4fc1-702a-4ac4-969a-0b505edf527f is the policy ID for the policy called “Default Policy”.

Before proceeding to the next step, confirm that you can see all 4 of the REST Operations under the HTTP-REST inventory item as shown below

CREATING REUSABLE VRO WORKFLOWS

In the following section, we'll develop reusable vRO workflows designed to create vROPs symptom and alert definitions, and subsequently integrate them into a policy. Reusable workflows promote code reusability, improving development efficiency, and enhancing the maintainability and scalability of software systems. The custom workflows in this lab have already been precreated but we will make edits throughout the lab to make the workflows usable.

Note, in order to successfully run any workflows that use the vROPs API REST operations, we'll need to pass the token information into the the workflow.  We'll achieve this by embedding the token workflow within the active workflow and transferring the token as a parameter.  

The token authentication workflow has already been preconfigured but we still need to add the REST host that was created in the previous steps.

From the left side, select Workflows

1. Filter for Livefire Class Get vROPs Token

2. Click on OPEN to view and edit the workflow

1.  Go to the Variables tab and click on restOperation, a new window will appear

2. Click on the Value line

1. Expand the dropdowns until you see the vROPs token Operation

2. Click on SELECT

1. Click on SAVE to save the configuration

1. If you get a "Validation is not successful" message, select CONTINUE ANYWAY or to fix see below:

But if you want to fix the problem, then do this:

  • Go to the Variables tab.
  • Select hostResource.
  • Click DELETE.
  • Click NEW.
  • Set Name to hostResource.
  • Enter REST:RESTHost into the Type text box, and select REST:RESTHost in the popup window.
  • Click the Value text field.
  • Select HTTP REST > vROPS.
  • Click SELECT.
  • Click CREATE.
  • Click the Schema tab.
  • Click the schema element labeled “Scripting”.
  • Expand Inputs/Outputs.
  • Locate the hostResource input and click Select variable.
  • Choose hostResource from the popup window.

Now if you click VALIDATE, the error message will not appear. A warning message will still appear, but ignore it.

​​​​​​​You can now run the workflow to validate a token is being created as designed.

  1. Click on RUN at the top of the workflow
  1. Wait for the green Completed status
  2. Click on the log tab at the bottom to view the token

Now that we have the token workflow successfully configured, we can embed it into the Alert Creation workflow.  This has already been preconfigured but we still need to add the REST host and operations that were created in the previous steps.

From the left side, select Workflows

1. Filter for Create vROPs Alert and Symptom Definitions (Livefire)

2. Click on OPEN to view and edit the workflow

1.  Go to the Variables tab and note that we have 3 restOperations to configure

1. click on restOperation_AlertDefAdd, a new window will appear

2. Click on the Value line

1. Expand the dropdowns until you see the vROPs  Alert Definition.

2. Click on SELECT

1. Click on SAVE to save the configuration

1. Repeat these steps for the following:  (DO NOT SKIP)

- restOperation_PolicyAdd

- restOperation_SymptomDefAdd

2.  Once completed, SAVE the workflow - (Feel free to view the workflow, specifically the Schema tab to view how the workflow is configured.  Click on the item and the Scripting tab (if applicable) to view the associated code)

We will now run the workflow to test

1. Click on RUN at the top of the workflow

2. Enter the following:

Symptom_Definition_Name - VM Is Powered Off

Alert_Definition_Name - Virtual Machine is Powered Off

Alert_Definition_Description -  Virtual Machine is Down

Click on RUN to run the workflow

  1. Wait for the green Completed status   (If you get an invalid username error, please rerun the workflow)
  2. Click on the log tab at the bottom to view the output and status of the REST Requests.  You'll see 200 and 201 Status Codes for each REST operation that was called in the workflow which means the REST API Calls to vROPs were successful.  Feel free to view the logs for more information regarding the REST Calls.

Now let's see the real proof by going to vROPS and confirming the Alerts and Symptoms exist and are associated to the default policy as designed.

1. Log into vROPS at https://aria-ops.vcf.sddc.lab

username - vropsapi

password - VMware123!

Note - We are using the same credentials as provided when configuring the vROPS API token.  This account has admin privileges on all objects allowing it to run API calls on all objects in the vROPS instance.

Let's take a look at the Alerts and Symptoms

1. Click on Operations on the left side

2. Click on Configurations

3. Click on Symptom Definitions

1. In the filter bar, enter the Symptom Definition that we created in the Orchestrator REST Call workflow. (VM is Powered Off)

2. Check the Modified By field which shows the user that created the symptom (vropsapi)

1. Click on the VM is Powered Off symptom definition to view the settings (Note: Excluding the definition name which we manually entered, the remaining settings were defined in the Create vROPs Alert and Symptom Definitions (Livefire) workflow that was run in Orchestrator)

Now let's take a look at the Alert Definition

LocaleContent.title: 2. Creating a vROPS Webhook Alert Notification
LocaleContent.content:
In vROPs, we are able to set up a webhook that will trigger a workflow in vRO, allowing us to automate actions based on events detected by vROps.

In this lab, we will set up a webhook within vRealize Operations (vROps) to trigger a specific workflow in vSphere Orchestrator (vRO) whenever a virtual machine is powered down in vCenter. The workflow, named "Livefire Class Start a Virtual Machine and Wait" will be initiated automatically in response to VM power-down events detected by vROps.

The lab entails configuring the webhook outbound plugin in vROps to communicate with vRO, ensuring seamless integration between the two systems. We will define the payload structure to transmit relevant data to vRO, facilitating the execution of the designated workflow.

By completing this lab, we will gain hands-on experience in orchestrating VM operations using vROps webhooks, enhancing automation capabilities and operational efficiency within virtualized environments.

In this lab we'll need the following:

- An Orchestrator Workflow - which is the workflow that is being called by vROPs when triggered

- An Outbound Instance - which is a configuration that allows vROPs to send data or notifications to external systems or endpoints.

- A Payload template - which is a predefined structure or format for data that is sent out as part of notifications or integrations with external systems.

- A Notification - which is how we'll integrate the above listed items to send out info on alerts

- It's a good idea to grab a VM name from your previous deployment now...it will be used for testing purposes later in the lab

In this lab, we configured the webhook outbound plugin in vRealize Operations (vROps) to facilitate communication with external systems, particularly Orchestrator's REST API. We crafted a payload tailored to interact effectively with Orchestrator's API, ensuring seamless data transmission. Additionally, we created a notification mechanism leveraging custom alert definitions, enabling timely alerts for critical events. Finally, we validated the configuration, ensuring alignment with the Orchestrator schema, thus confirming the reliability of the integration.  In the next lab we will test :)

Create New Outbound Instance

We'll first create an Outbound Instance using the Webhook Notification Plugin

Log into vRealize Operations at https://aria-ops.vcf.sddc.lab/

username - vropsapi

password - VMware123!

1. Proceed to the Operations tab

2. Click on Configurations

3. Locate Outbound Settings

1. Click on ADD to add a new setting

Enter the following:

1. Plugin Type:  Webhook Notification Plugin

2. Instance Name: Aria Orchestrator

3. Url: https://aria-auto.vcf.sddc.lab:443/vco/api

4. Connection 20

5. HTTP Proxy: (leave blank)

6. Credential type:  Basic Authentication

7. Credential: (see below)

Select the + sign to the right of the info button to enter the following credentials:

  Name - vRO

  User name - configadmin

  Password - VMware123!

Click SAVE to save the credentials

8. Connection Timeout: 30

9. Click SAVE

10. You may see a "Failed to post to the server Proceed Anyway message".  (This is because we have not yet entered the payload information that will be submitted with this request.)  Click on YES to proceed

11.  Review and Accept Certificate if prompted

Create the Payload Template

We will now create a payload template to align with the requirements of the Orchestrator REST API for the Livefire Class Start virtual machine and wait workflow

1. Proceed to the Operations tab

2. Click on Configurations

3. Locate Payload Templates

Click on ADD to add a new template

Enter in the following:

1. Name - vRO Workflow Template

2. Outbound method - Webhook Notification Plugin (which is the type of method we configured in the previous steps)

3. Click on NEXT

We will now the an Object type - an "object type" refers to a classification or category of entities within your environment that vROps monitors and manages. These object types represent different resources such as virtual machines, hosts, clusters, datastores, applications, and various infrastructure components.  We will use a vCenter / Virtual Machine object type for this lab.

1. Click on the dropdown and expand vCenter (at the top of the list)

2. Select Virtual Machine

Enter the following Metrics and Properties by locating the Summary|Guest Operating System|Hostname under Favorites/Configuration. Drag to the Virtual Machine window as shown:

Click on OK and NEXT to proceed to the next tab

On the Payload Details tab, we'll define the specific HTTP method appended to the URL in the plugin instance, along with specifying the content type typically used in REST APIs, and crafting the JSON body precisely as expected by Orchestrator. This is also where the object content becomes relevant if selected. On the right side, we have the parameters available: the capitalized letters are always present, while the lowercase letters represent any additional parameters that might have been added in the previous screen.

Enter the following as shown:

Input Properties - No

Different payload details - No

Endpoint URL - /workflows/f873c461-37db-43b6-926e-9251d0526836/executions

     (NOTE - The execution URL uses the workflow ID which can be found inside the Orchestrator workflow on the Summary tab, in this case we are using the "Livefire Class Start a virtual machine and wait" worklfow)

Content Type - application/json

Custom Headers - accept defaults

HTTP Method - POST

Add the following to the Payload of the request


{
   "parameters":[
     {
        "value":{
	  "string":{
             "value": "${RESOURCE_NAME}"
          }
},
        "type":"VC:VirtualMachine",
	"name":"vm",
        "scope":"local"
     }  
   ]
}

Click on CREATE to save

Update the Alert Definition

OK now that we have everything created, we can put it all together inside a notification. But before we do, let's update the alert definition we created in the previous lab to match the severity level we'll use in the notification.

1. Proceed to the Operations tab

2. Click on Configurations

3. Locate Alert Definitions

1. Filter for the "Virtual Machine is Powered Off" Alert Definition

Click on the ellipses to the left of the alert definition and select Edit

1. Expand Advanced Settings

2. Change the Criticality setting to Critical

3. Click on UPDATE to save

Create an Alert Notification

Now let's create the alert notification

1. Proceed to the Operations tab

2. Click on Configurations

3. Locate Notifications

Click on ADD to add a new notification

Enter the following:

1. Name - VM Power On Required

2. Enable the Notification Status slider

3. Click on NEXT to proceed with the configuration

The Define Criteria tab allows you to specify the conditions under which notifications should be triggered. This tab provides a way to filter and narrow down the alerts that should generate notifications based on specific criteria.  By configuring these criteria, you can tailor notifications to your specific monitoring requirements and ensure that you only receive notifications for the alerts that are most relevant to you. This helps reduce notification noise and ensures that you are promptly alerted to critical issues in your environment.

Enter the following:

1. Under Object Scope

     Criteria - Object Type > VCenter > Virtual Machine

2. Under Alert Scope:

    Category -  Alert Definition

    Filter for Alert Definition  - Virtual machine is Powered Off     (NOTE- we are using the alert definition that was created in the previous lab)

          Select and drag to the "Drop alert definition here" box

          Click OK to save the alert definition

1. Enable the Notification Heartbeat

(Accept remaining defaults on this tab)

3. Click on NEXT

Next we will add the Aria Orchestrator Webhook that was created in the previous steps

Update with the following:

1. Outbound method - Webhook Notification Plugin

2. Instance - Aria Orchestrator

3. Click on NEXT

Next we will add the vRO Workflow Template that was created in the previous steps

Update with the following:

1. Payload Template - vRO Workflow Template

    Note - if we expand the template we are able to view the payload details as previously defined

2. Click on NEXT

We are now we able to validate the notification configuration.

1. Click on INITIATE PROCESS

A pop up window will appear allowing you to choose and alert definition and object to test against.

1. Filter on and select "Virtual Machine is Powered Off" for the Alert Definition (hit NEXT)

2. For your object, filter on and select a VM from your previous deployment (this will also be the used to test the Webhook Alert Notification)

3. Click on VALIDATE CONFIGURATION

You should see the following if the notification configuration passes the test

On the same page under the Body tab, you can also view the payload parameters that are being passed in the Webhook to the Orchestrator workflow - (this can be very helpful for troubleshooting)

Click on SAVE to save the notification configuration.

LocaleContent.title: 4. Creating a vRSLCM Configuration Using REST APIs in Orchestrator
LocaleContent.content:
In our lab solution, we've devised a solution utilizing VMware Aria Suite Lifecycle as a centralized content manager for vROps configurations, all orchestrated through REST APIs within Orchestrator. This approach ensures seamless management and deployment of vROps configurations across VMware environments. To enhance usability, we'll also develop a Service Broker catalog item, allowing end-users to easily access and utilize this functionality. This not only promotes reusability but also empowers users to efficiently consume vROps configurations, ultimately streamlining operations and enhancing overall system agility.

In this lab session, we focused on configuring VMware vRealize Orchestrator (vRO) workflows to execute REST API calls to VMware Aria Suite Lifecycle (vRSLCM). These workflows enabled us to gather content from vRealize Operations (vROps) and improve the usability of the Service Broker platform by seamlessly integrating this functionality.

ADD a REST HOST

Testing Testing

username - vcfadmin@local

In this lab session, we successfully tested the functionality of the previous lab where we created a VMware vRealize Suite Lifecycle Manager workflow in Orchestrator and integrated it into Service Broker. Through comprehensive testing, we confirmed that the Service Broker catalog item operates seamlessly, allowing us to efficiently capture vROps configuration content as expected.
